awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for Real World Cryptography 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
Now in its eleventh year, Real World Crypto is an established premier venue which features presentations of ideas, advances and challenges from across academia and industry on a broad specter of cryptography and security topics. This includes invited talks on some of the most impactful developments in the field as well as a number of contributed talks selected among an ever growing number of submissions.

This award enables student travel awards, and members of underrepresented groups are especially encouraged to apply. Students, who otherwise would not be able to attend, will be exposed to the state of the art in theoretical and applied cryptography, as presented by experts from both academia and industry. In addition, students will have opportunities to learn about internships and job openings, and to discuss employment and collaboration with more senior members of the field. The results of the conference, and the awards made possible by sponsors will be made available to the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The Real World Cryptography (RWC) Symposium 2023 was held in Tokyo, Japan, from March 27–29, 2023, at the Plaza Heisei.  This project supported funding for students from US institutions to attend. 

There were 649 in-person attendees, of which 184 were students. A total of 43 countries were represented among the affiliations of attendees; the top 10 countries by participant affiliation were: USA (236), Japan (127), Germany (58), France (52), Switzerland (49), UK (42), Canada (20), Belgium (18), South Korea (16), and the Netherlands (16). 

The main program of the conference featured 43 contributed and invited talks, including 3 talks by NSF-supported speakers. Highlights of the technical program included 3 invited talks by industry researchers: from Apple, Cloudflare, and Fastly on "iCloud Private Relay: Multi-hop Internet privacy at scale"; from Meta on "WhatsApp End-to-End Encrypted Backups"; and from Google on "Design, Applied Cryptography, and Humans". The program included sessions on post-quantum cryptography, network security and key exchange, building and breaking secure systems, crypto for people, side channels & backdoors, messaging & encryption, fully homomorphic encryption and multi-party computation, standardization, secure implementations, privacy and zero-knowledge proofs, threshold cryptography, and advanced encryption. 

The conference also included several networking/meetup activities for attendees in underrepresented groups, including an LGBTQ+ lunch meetup and a women's networking lunch organized by an NSF-supported attendee. There were also 4 co-located events affiliated with the RWC conference held on the days before and after the main conference (March 26: Workshop on Real World Post Quantum Cryptography; 2nd Annual FHE.org Conference on Fully Homomorphic Encryption; March 30: Open Source Cryptography Workshop; Randomness Summit 2023).

Students funded through this project were selected from US institutions (eligibility requirement for this funding). We aimed to fund first applicants from underrepresented groups as well as underrepresented institutions in order to extend our reach to as many students who can benefit from attending the conference, as possible. We took into consideration the funding of the advisor and aimed to fund first students who were not going to be able to attend the conference without a stipend. Priority was also given to applicants who had accepted presentations and were giving a talk at the conference. The exact amount awarded reflected the estimated travel costs from the student institution to Tokyo, the funding provided to students of the specific advisor and the specific institution in order to provide maximally broad reach for the funding, and whether the student is giving a talk and thus is crucial to attend.

Twelve participants, eight of whom are female, from ten different institutions, were selected to be funded through this project. The funding supported the participants' travel, accommodation, and registration. It allowed them to be exposed to the state of the art in theoretical and applied cryptography, as presented by experts from both academia and industry. In addition, it gave them the opportunity to learn about internships and job openings, and to discuss employment and collaboration with more senior members of the field. 


Last Modified: 01/03/2025
Modified by: Tal G Malkin

The Real World Cryptography (RWC) Symposium 2023 was held in Tokyo, Japan, from March 2729, 2023, at the Plaza Heisei. This project supported funding for students from US institutions to attend.


There were 649 in-person attendees, of which 184 were students. A total of 43 countries were represented among the affiliations of attendees; the top 10 countries by participant affiliation were: USA (236), Japan (127), Germany (58), France (52), Switzerland (49), UK (42), Canada (20), Belgium (18), South Korea (16), and the Netherlands (16).

The conference also included several networking/meetup activities for attendees in underrepresented groups, including an LGBTQ+ lunch meetup and a women's networking lunch organized by an NSF-supported attendee. There were also 4 co-located events affiliated with the RWC conference held on the days before and after the main conference (March 26: Workshop on Real World Post Quantum Cryptography; 2nd Annual FHE.org Conference on Fully Homomorphic Encryption; March 30: Open Source Cryptography Workshop; Randomness Summit 2023).






Students funded through this project were selected from US institutions (eligibility requirement for this funding). We aimed to fund first applicants from underrepresented groups as well as underrepresented institutions in order to extend our reach to as many students who can benefit from attending the conference, as possible. We took into consideration the funding of the advisor and aimed to fund first students who were not going to be able to attend the conference without a stipend. Twelve participants, eight of whom are female, from ten different institutions, were selected to be funded through this project.The funding supported the participants' travel, accommodation, and registration. It allowed them to be exposed to the state of the art in theoretical and applied cryptography, as presented by experts from both academia and industry. In addition, it gave them the opportunity to learn about internships and job openings, and to discuss employment and collaboration with more senior members of the field.
